awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Coding-based Mechanisms for Building Secure Cloud Storage Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
A wide range of cloud services and applications operate on sensitive data such as business, personal, and governmental information. This renders security and privacy as the most critical concerns in the cloud era. The objective of this project is to question the separation approach in the design of security and reliability features of storage systems, and to investigate new, coding-based security mechanisms based on a joint-design principle. The proposed program will result in a myriad of outcomes. The solutions include effective ways of thwarting cyber attacks, ensuring data availability, and establishing trust between the parties of storage architectures. These infrastructures are the backbones of several systems including cloud computing, peer-to-peer, and content delivery networks. The proposed research together with its far-reaching effects ensure the well-being of these critical infrastructures of the nation by increasing their security and resilience - supporting business, consumer, and military applications. The educational plan of the project, capitalizing on the proposed perspective, aims to train students with principles of multiple fields and their interactions, preparing them for leading-edge STEM positions.

The main directions of this project include a) designing codeword allocations to resolve data connectivity challenges when system components fail, b) utilizing secret keys stored at clients in encoding to reduce the cost of information theoretic security, c) building data mixtures through interference alignment principle to resolve privacy problems, and d) designing codes to facilitate challenge-based cryptographic protocols for establishing trust mechanisms between providers and clients. Revealing the benefits that can be leveraged from such a coding-based security approach, this research addresses the challenges in identifying appropriate metrics for data availability and security, characterizing fundamental limits based on these models, and constructing schemes that achieve optimal performance. The proposed effort is interdisciplinary in nature, borrowing tools from coding theory, information theory, cryptography, and networking, and will develop new techniques in these fields.

por.por_cntn:
A wide range of communications and storage systems operate on sensitive data such as business, personal, and governmental information. This renders security and privacy as the most critical concerns, especially in the cloud era. Building upon synergies between the principles of information theory, coding theory, cryptography, and stochastic optimization, this project developed novel techniques to improve reliability, availability, confidentiality and privacy of these systems. In particular, the project led to the following developments.

a) We studied broadcast channels under different secrecy constraints, where a transmitter sends information to two receivers, while trying to make messages secret from an external eavesdropper. We have constructed secure communication schemes for this problem and studied the fundamental limits. Our results characterized the capacity region for the special case of linear deterministic model, and included a constant gap to capacity region for the Gaussian case. Overall, by considering different secrecy notions, we got a better understanding of the trade-off between secrecy level and communication throughput.

b) We have analyzed vulnerabilities of Massive MIMO systems and developed techniques to counter pilot contamination attacks. In these communication systems, base stations obtain channel state information based on pilot transmissions and these transmissions leak information. We have developed new frameworks to study this problem, where adversaries pollute pilot transmissions and/or degrade data transmissions. Our solutions utilized stochastic optimization, Lagrangian methods, and game theory. One of our results showed that the attacks can degrade the network throughput by more than half.

c) We studied the relationship between Private Information Retrieval (PIR) and locally recoverable codes (LRCs). In the PIR problem, user wants to privately download one or more messages belonging to a database with copies stored on a single or multiple remote servers. In the LRC problem, each symbol of the code can be recovered from a limited number of other symbols. We showed that 1) single-message PIR schemes are equivalent to LRCs, and 2) PIR schemes allowing multiple message retrieval are equivalent to a class of LRCs referred to as cooperative LRCs, where multiple symbols can be recovered from a small set of other code symbols. The connection between these two problems enabled a better understanding of them and paved the way for further developments in these areas.

d) We studied the problem of privacy preserving distributed learning, in particular we focused on the Federated Learning (FL) scenario, where distributed clients each with local data communicate with a central server to compute a machine learning model. Model updates from these clients leak significant information unless additional privacy preserving mechanisms are adopted. We have developed novel secret sharing schemes that lower computation costs of traditional approaches. Building upon this result, we also proposed scalable secure aggregation protocols that effectively trade-off between communication cost, computation cost, reliability level, and privacy level.
